Recording 1: Lecture - Biology
Narrator: "You will hear part of a lecture in a biology class. First, you have some time to look at questions 1 to 5."

"Now listen carefully and answer questions 1 to 5."
Professor:
"Today, we'll discuss symbiosis—a close ecological relationship between organisms of different species. There are three main types: mutualism, where both benefit; commensalism, where one benefits without harming the other; and parasitism, where one benefits at the other's expense. A classic example of mutualism is the relationship between bees and flowers. Bees get nectar, while flowers get pollinated. In contrast, tapeworms in mammals represent parasitism. Understanding these interactions helps us evaluate ecosystem health."

questions.question_text: What is the main topic of the lecture?
options: The role of bees in pollination
The three types of symbiotic relationships
The impact of parasites on mammals
Methods to evaluate ecosystem health
questions.correct_answer: The three types of symbiotic relationships

questions.question_text: According to the professor, what defines commensalism?
options: Both species benefit from the relationship
One species benefits while the other is harmed
One species benefits without affecting the other
Both species compete for the same resources
questions.correct_answer: One species benefits without affecting the other

questions.question_text: Why does the professor mention bees and flowers?
options: To explain how parasitism works
To illustrate an example of mutualism
To show a case of commensalism
To discuss the decline of bee populations
questions.correct_answer: To illustrate an example of mutualism

questions.question_text: What is the significance of understanding symbiotic relationships, according to the lecture?
options: It helps in breeding new species
It allows scientists to control ecosystems
It aids in evaluating ecosystem health
It prevents the spread of parasites
questions.correct_answer: It allows scientists to control ecosystems

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following are examples mentioned in the lecture?
options: A bird building a nest in a tree (commensalism)
Bees pollinating flowers while collecting nectar (mutualism)
Tapeworms living inside mammals (parasitism)
A lion hunting a zebra (predation)
correct_answer: Bees pollinating flowers while collecting nectar (mutualism)

Recording 2: Conversation - Campus Life
Narrator: "You will hear a conversation between a student and a librarian. First, you have some time to look at questions 6 to 10."

"Now listen carefully and answer questions 6 to 10."
Student: "Hi! I'm working on a research paper about renewable energy, but I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed by the database search. Do you have any advice?"
Librarian: "Absolutely! Here's a good starting point: First, narrow your results by selecting 'peer-reviewed' and limiting the publication date to the last five years. Instead of broad terms like 'renewable energy,' try more specific keywords—for example, 'solar panel efficiency trends' or 'offshore wind power advancements.' Oh, and a pro tip—if you find one solid article, skim its references for even more useful sources!"
Student: "That's really helpful! Thanks so much!"
Librarian: "You're welcome! Let me know if you'd like help refining your keywords or accessing any full-text articles."

questions.question_text: What is the student's main concern?
options: They cannot find any books on renewable energy
They feel overwhelmed by the database search
They need help formatting their research paper
They want to borrow a laptop from the library
questions.correct_answer: They feel overwhelmed by the database search

questions.question_text: What is the librarian's FIRST suggestion for improving the search?
options: Use only books instead of online databases
Select 'peer-reviewed' and limit publication dates
Ask a professor for recommended sources
Search for the broadest possible keywords

questions.question_text: What does the librarian recommend regarding keywords?
options: Always use general terms like 'renewable energy'
Avoid using recent publications for accuracy
Try more specific phrases like 'solar panel efficiency trends'
Only rely on sources from the last ten years
questions.correct_answer: Try more specific phrases like 'solar panel efficiency trends'

questions.question_text: What is the librarian's 'pro tip' for finding additional sources?
options: Copy entire articles and paste them into the paper
Check the references of a good article for more leads
Only use sources from the library's physical collection
Skip peer-reviewed articles to save time
questions.correct_answer: Check the references of a good article for more leads

questions.question_text: Which TWO pieces of advice does the librarian give?
options: Use broad search terms to get more results
Focus on peer-reviewed and recent articles
Avoid citing references from other papers
Check the references of useful articles for more sources
correct_answer: Focus on peer-reviewed and recent articles
Check the references of useful articles for more sources

recordings.audio_text:
Recording 3: Lecture - History
Narrator: "You will hear part of a lecture in a history class. The topic is the Industrial Revolution. First, you have some time to look at questions 11 to 15."

"Now listen carefully and answer questions 11 to 15."
Professor:
"Today, we'll discuss the Industrial Revolution, a pivotal period that began in 18th-century Britain. Three key factors drove this transformation: technological innovations like the steam engine, rapid population growth, and abundant access to coal as an energy source. As factories replaced traditional manual labor, production efficiency soared. However, this shift also led to unintended consequences, such as urban overcrowding, pollution, and harsh working conditions—often with 14-hour workdays and child labor. In response, the late 19th century saw the rise of labor movements advocating for workers' rights, including shorter hours and safer environments. These reforms laid the groundwork for modern labor laws."

questions.question_text: Where did the Industrial Revolution begin?
options: France
Germany
Britain
United States

questions.question_text: What was NOT mentioned as a key factor driving the Industrial Revolution?
options: Technological innovations like the steam engine
Rapid population growth
Government policies promoting trade
Abundant access to coal

questions.question_text: What was one major consequence of the shift to factory labor?
options: Decreased production efficiency
Improved air quality in cities
Urban overcrowding and pollution
Shorter workdays for children

questions.question_text: What did labor movements in the late 19th century advocate for?
options: Longer work hours to increase profits
The return to manual labor systems
Workers' rights, including safer conditions
Reduced access to education for children

questions.question_text: Which TWO of the following were direct outcomes of the Industrial Revolution?
options: Invention of the internet
Harsh working conditions with 14-hour days
Decline in urban population density
Rise of labor movements for workers' rights
Replacement of coal with solar energy
correct_answer: Rise of labor movements for workers' rights

Recording 4: Conversation - Student & Professor
Narrator: "You will hear a conversation between a student and an astronomy professor. The topic is the difference between asteroids and comets. First, you have some time to look at questions 16 to 20."

"Now listen carefully and answer questions 16 to 20."
Student:
"Professor, I've been studying for the midterm, but I'm still unclear about how asteroids and comets differ. The textbook calls them both 'minor celestial bodies,' but they seem completely different..."
Professor:
"That's an important distinction! Let me clarify: Asteroids are essentially rocky fragments, most orbiting in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter. Comets are icy bodies originating from the outer solar system - what astronomers call 'dirty snowballs' of frozen gases and dust."
Student:
"So when we see comets with bright tails, is that because of the ice?"
Professor:
"Exactly right! As comets approach the sun, solar radiation vaporizes their ice, creating two distinct tails: a dust tail and an ion tail. That's why famous comets like Halley's or Hale-Bopp become so spectacular - their tails can stretch millions of kilometers!"
Student:
"And asteroids never display this behavior?"
Professor:
"Never. Without volatile ices, asteroids remain inert. They may collide and create debris fields - in fact, we think some meteor showers come from asteroid fragments - but you'll never see an asteroid with a glowing tail."

questions.question_text: What is the main topic of the conversation?
options: The formation of meteor showers
Differences between asteroids and comets
The discovery of Halley's Comet
How solar radiation affects planets

questions.question_text: Where are most asteroids located, according to the professor?
options: Beyond Neptune
Between Mars and Jupiter
Near Earth's atmosphere
Orbiting the Sun randomly

questions.question_text: What causes comets to develop visible tails?
options: Collisions with other celestial bodies
Solar radiation vaporizing their ice
Magnetic fields in space
Dust accumulating over time

questions.question_text: Why can't asteroids develop glowing tails like comets?
options: They are too small to be visible
They lack volatile ices
They move too quickly through space
They are made of pure metal

questions.question_text: Which TWO statements about comets are true based on the conversation?
options: They originate from the asteroid belt
They are nicknamed "dirty snowballs"
Their tails always point away from Earth
They can develop both dust and ion tails
Famous examples include Hale-Bopp
correct_answer: They can develop both dust and ion tails
